  José Manuel Fernandes (PPE), in writing. – (PT) This recommendation for second reading, by Mr Lehne, is aimed at the adoption of the directive of Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 78/660/EEC on the annual accounts of certain types of companies as regards micro-entities, that is, a subgroup of micro-enterprises, the majority of which operate their business at a local level. It concerns a definition that is not included in Commission Recommendation 2003/361/EC, which defines micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, but which sets them out for accounting reasons. Like other companies, micro-entities are obliged to publish their accounts annually, which represents a significant burden in view of their turnover. However, Member States may exempt micro-entities from having to publish their accounts under certain conditions. The aim of this directive is therefore to facilitate business activity for micro-entities by reducing the administrative burden. Given the importance of these companies for the local economy and their contribution to national GDP, I welcome the proposals to amend the amounts up to which they can be granted exemption, namely, changing the balance sheet total from EUR 250 000 to EUR 350 000, and the net turnover from EUR 500 000 to EUR 700 000, and I am voting for this recommendation.

 
  
 		 

  João Ferreira (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) The preparation and publication of annual accounts can be a heavy burden for some micro-entities. This report recognises this fact, and therefore advocates that micro-entities be exempt from the general publication requirement. It is intended that the Member States should be authorised to exempt micro-entities from the general publication requirement, provided that balance sheet information is duly filed, in accordance with national law, with at least one designated competent authority, and that the information is transmitted to the business register.

As such, the Member States will be able to grant exemption from some of the obligations set out in the current directive to companies which, on their balance sheet dates, do not exceed the limits of two of the following three criteria: balance sheet total, EUR 350 000; net turnover, EUR 700 000; average number of employees during the financial year, 10.

While we recognise the importance of alleviating some of the constraints, which are manifold and ever greater, that are weighing on micro and small enterprises, particularly in this time of recession and severe crisis, this proposal departs from the Commission’s initial proposal in some respects, so we have some reservations.

 
  
 		 

  Ilda Figueiredo (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) The aim of this report on the annual accounts as regards micro-entities is to permit Member States to exempt micro-entities from the general publication requirement, provided that balance sheet information is duly filed, in accordance with national law, with at least one designated competent authority, and that the information is transmitted to the business register.

In accordance with paragraphs 2 and 3, the Member States may provide exemptions from certain obligations set out in the current directive to companies which, on their balance sheet dates, do not exceed the limits of two of the following three criteria for micro-entities, including a balance sheet total of EUR 350 000.

 
  
 		 

  Monika Flašíková Benová (S&D), in writing. – (SK) The European Council of 8-9 March 2007 stressed in its conclusions that reducing administrative burdens is important for boosting the European economy and that a strong joint effort to reduce administrative burdens within the EU is necessary. Accounting has been identified as one of the key areas for reducing administrative burdens for companies within the EU. The High-Level Group of Independent Stakeholders on Administrative Burdens, in its opinion of 10 July 2008, called for rapid enactment of an option for Member States to exempt micro-entities from the obligation to draw up annual accounts in accordance with Directive 78/660/EEC. Subsequently, in its resolution of 18 December 2008 on accounting requirements as regards small and medium-sized enterprises, particularly micro-entities, the European Parliament called on the Commission to present a legislative proposal that would allow Member States to exempt micro-entities from the scope of this directive. The objective of this directive, namely, to reduce administrative burdens on micro-entities, cannot be achieved to a sufficient degree by the Member States, and therefore, because of its effects, can be better achieved at EU level. For this reason, too, it would be appropriate to amend Directive 78/660/EEC accordingly.

 
  
 		 

  Lorenzo Fontana (EFD), in writing. – (IT) I am voting in favour of the amendment of the directive under scrutiny since it aims to resolve one of the unfortunate problems that beset businesses, even in the EU: the administrative and bureaucratic costs that slow down and add pointless complications to doing business.   Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D), in writing. – (PL) I am pleased to see that the report just presented introduces enhancements to European legislation, a process I have been personally involved in for many years. It was on this basis that the action plan to reduce the administrative burdens for European enterprises by 25% by 2012 was approved in March 2007.

Moreover, the European Economic Recovery Plan called on Member States and the EU to take immediate steps to reduce the administrative burdens for SMEs and micro-entities. On 29 February 2009, the European Commission prepared the proposed amendments to Directive 78/660/EEC on the annual accounts of certain types of companies. In this case, the obligation laid down in Article 47 of Directive 78/660/EEC to publish all accounting documents in accordance with Article 3(5) of Directive 2009/101/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 September 2009 on coordination of safeguards which, for the protection of the interests of members and third parties, are required by Member States of companies within the meaning of the second paragraph of Article 48 of the Treaty, with a view to making such safeguards equivalent, would not apply.   Charalampos Angourakis (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (EL) The regulation on the reduction of the national contribution to the EU budget for farmers advertised, like the regulation on the NSRF, by the EU, the PASOK government and now the black-front PASOK, New Democracy and LAOS government as a ‘national success’, and proof of the solidarity of the EU, is yet another attempt to dupe the people.

What the political representatives of capital are hiding is this: that the euro-unifying budget – in reality, the workers’ money – is not going to increase and will remain at the same level, meaning that there will be fewer investments in projects financed from the euro-unifying funds. The most important thing, however, is that, based on the eligibility criteria for projects financed by the EU, these projects will be projects that serve the needs of the monopoly groups and their competitiveness and profitability, not projects and infrastructures for the benefit of poor, medium-sized farms that will satisfy grassroots requirements. This proves, yet again, that not only is the EU not a ‘union of solidarity’; it is an imperialist union of the monopolies set up to serve their interests, an iron bar to be wielded against the people and the working/grassroots movement.

 
  
 		 

  Sophie Auconie (PPE), in writing. – (FR) During this period of economic and financial crisis, European solidarity is more relevant than ever. This European solidarity is at the heart of the Union’s rural development policy, which grants aid to regions experiencing slow economic growth through the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD). At the moment, certain Member States are no longer in a position to cofinance some development projects, due to a lack of funds. As I am in favour of a strong rural development policy, I voted in favour of a European Parliament resolution aimed at temporarily increasing the cofinancing rate for certain projects (which may be increased to 95% in some very specific cases). These projects are aimed at, and should play a part in, the economic recovery of Greece and Portugal in particular.

 
  
 		 

  Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this legislative resolution and welcomed the European Parliament’s position at first reading. The Commission’s proposal for a regulation proposes temporarily increasing the Union’s maximum cofinancing rate (up to 95%) for programmes running in Member States which receive support under the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism (Greece, Ireland and Portugal) and the balance of payments facility for non-euro area Member States (Latvia, Hungary and Romania). Due to budgetary constraints, some Member States that receive assistance under aid programmes risk failing to fulfil their commitments and losing Community support (unless they provide proof that they are allocating matching national funding no later than two years after the year initially set for the payment). The instrument proposed by the Commission will enable these Member States to reduce their contribution when cofinancing projects with the European Union. Possibilities will thus arise to release funds already allocated from the EU Cohesion Fund and Rural Development or Fisheries Funds earlier and to begin implementing programmes postponed due to a lack of national funding.

 
  
 		 

  Regina Bastos (PPE), in writing. – (PT) As a result of the current economic, financial and social crisis that is affecting Europe, some Member States are facing budgetary restraints, which may prevent them from fulfilling their commitments to cofinanced EU programmes. These Member States thus risk losing EU support from the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development. This report adopts the increased rates of cofinancing for EU rural development funds intended for Portugal, Greece, Ireland, Romania and Latvia, and the EU’s contribution can cover 95% of the total costs of projects in this area. These measures will remain in force until the end of 2013. The aim is therefore to help the economic recovery of these countries, allowing programmes to be launched that would not have been implemented until then due to a lack of national funding. I voted for this report for those reasons.

 
  
 		 

  Jean-Luc Bennahmias (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) With the adoption of Paolo De Castro’s report, the EU finally seems capable of proving that it is both useful and unified. In order to respond to the context of the crisis, Europe has decided to take transitional measures until the end of 2013. It will grant Member States in financial difficulty, such as Greece, Romania and Portugal, very favourable cofinancing rates of up to 95% so that they can finance rural development projects and hence encourage economic recovery. I supported the increase in EAFRD cofinancing rates in order to ensure that those EU countries with poor growth prospects and weakened public finances do not see the implementation of their projects stopped on the ground. However, this positive policy of supporting countries in financial difficulty with regard to rural development should be accompanied by a similar policy for their regional development projects. By creating synergy between the projects financed by the various European funds, we can make an effective and sustainable contribution to the economic development and growth of those States.

 
  
 		 

  Mara Bizzotto (EFD), in writing. – (IT) I abstained because this measure addresses a sensitive issue where the effects of our actions are not entirely clear, despite what the report says.

Increasing the percentage of cofinancing for projects in some countries is sure to result in a reduction in the overall number of projects that can be funded under the European Rural Development Fund. I abstained because we do not know what effects a measure like this will have on the management of the fund in the countries concerned and on the quality of the results that the projects will bring.

 
  
 		 

  Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this report because with it, the European Parliament is approving the Commission’s proposal to temporarily increase the Union’s cofinancing rate when providing support from the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development to Member States which are facing budgetary constraints as a consequence of the financial and budgetary crisis that might prevent them from fulfilling their commitments in cofinanced Community programmes. Without these temporary measures, Member States such as Greece, Ireland, Portugal, Latvia and Romania and their economies would risk losing competitiveness in the long term. The European Parliament has therefore approved the Commission’s proposal to temporarily increase the Union’s cofinancing rate until 2013 to maintain the required level of investment in these countries and thus ensure their continued economic development. Such temporary measures will not have an impact on funds allocated to rural development as a whole.

 
  
 		 

  Vito Bonsignore (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted in favour of the report. As a consequence of the financial and budgetary crisis, some Member States have to face budgetary constraints which might prevent them from fulfilling their commitments in cofinanced Community programmes (structural and cohesion funds, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) and the European Fisheries Fund).

With reference to the EAFRD in particular, many Member States could lose their support unless they provide proof of spending matching national funds. I agree with the Commission’s proposal to temporarily increase the Union’s maximum cofinancing rate for programmes running in Member States that are subject to support of the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism (EFSM), such as Greece, Ireland and Portugal, and the balance of payments facility for non-euro area Member States, such as Latvia and Romania. This temporary increase in cofinancing, provided on application of the Member State concerned, would reduce the amount of matching national funds needed in 2011 and 2012 and would contribute to economic recovery in these Member States.

 
  
 		 

  Jan Březina (PPE), in writing. – (CS) As a consequence of the financial and budgetary crisis, some Member States are facing budgetary constraints which might prevent them from fulfilling their commitments in Community programmes that are cofinanced, especially from the Structural Funds. I understand, therefore, that the Commission, on the basis of these factors, is proposing temporarily to increase the maximum share of Union cofinancing for programmes under way in Member States that are drawing support from the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism (currently Greece, Ireland and Portugal) and from the balance of payments facility for non-euro area Member States (currently Latvia and Romania). This temporary increase in community cofinancing, provided on application of the Member State concerned, would reduce the amount of matching national funds needed in the budget years 2011 and 2012. It would thus contribute to an overall economic recovery in these Member States. I consider it important that the Commission proposal foresees no additional commitment appropriations. The additional payment appropriations needed to finance the increased EU support shall be transferred from the 2013 budget year to the 2011 and 2012 budget years. There will thus be no transfer of financial allocations between Member States, and I am therefore able to support this proposal.

These higher cofinancing rates for states in financial difficulty would be applied on a temporary basis only, until the end of 2013, but what kind of guarantee would the UK have that this legislation would not be continued or that the recipient nations would spend the funding wisely? The amendments made by Paolo De Castro and incorporated into the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1698/2005 will help at institutional level to safeguard more effective application of the measure to increase the rate of cofinancing of rural development programmes by the EAFRD.   Corina Creţu (S&D), in writing. – (RO) This is a technical document about the mechanisms and conditionality which are part of granting financial support to Member States experiencing difficulties, against the backdrop of the economic and sovereign debt crisis. The most important provision, which is my justification for voting to adopt this document, relates to the possibility of facilitating the management of the funding granted by the EU. In order to support increasing the pace of investment in Member States as well as in the affected regions, and to enhance the impact of the funding on the economy, the rate of the EAFRD contribution must be permitted to be increased to 95% of eligible public expenditure in the areas eligible under the convergence objective, or to 85% of eligible public expenditure in other regions facing severe difficulties in terms of their financial stability.

  José Manuel Fernandes (PPE), in writing. – (PT) This report concerns the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1698/2005 as regards certain rules relating to financial management for certain Member States threatened with serious difficulties with respect to their financial stability, as is the case with Portugal, Greece and Ireland. The budgetary constraints that these countries are experiencing may prevent them from investing the amounts allocated to them under the cofinanced EU programmes, namely, the structural and cohesion funds, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Fisheries Fund, as they do not have the matching national funds. This situation would force the Member States concerned to return those amounts to the EU, thus exacerbating the weakness of their economies even more. This proposal is aimed at temporarily increasing the maximum EU cofinancing rate for programmes running in the Member States that are subject to support from the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism. I welcome this proposal, for which I voted, and I am pleased with the adopted measures, as they discriminate in favour of the Member States that have been most affected by the economic and financial crisis and that are making great social sacrifices in order to ensure their economic recovery.

 
  
 		 

  João Ferreira (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) This proposal for a regulation recognises the negative effects of the severe crisis affecting certain Member States, such as Portugal, by using funds from cofinanced Community programmes such as the structural and cohesion funds and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development. Prior to this, restrictions on public investment, imposed under the pretext of the irrational Stability and Growth Pact (SGP), had the same effect.

We have long advocated the increase in the Union’s cofinancing rate for these Member States, which have difficulty in using EU funds at a time when they are most needed, due to the amounts of cofinancing required. After a regrettable delay, an increase in the Community contribution has now been proposed. In particular, for regions eligible under the convergence objective and the outermost regions, Community cofinancing is increased to 95%, while for other regions it will be 85%, until the end of 2013.

However, this proposal by the Commission does not include – as it should – the budget at the disposal of each of the countries that are in difficulty, so the practical result, owing to the reduction in national contributions, will be a reduction in the overall sum intended for investing. There is therefore a need for the Commission to consider actually increasing the Union funding available to these countries, as well as abolishing the irrational criteria of the SGP, thus freeing up the necessary public investment.

 
  
 		 

  Ilda Figueiredo (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) It is vital to finally adopt this proposal for a regulation, which recognises the negative effects of the severe crisis affecting certain Member States, such as Portugal, by using the funds from cofinanced Community programmes such as the structural and cohesion funds and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development. Prior to this, restrictions on public investment, imposed under the pretext of the irrational Stability and Growth Pact (SGP), had the same effect. We have long advocated the increase in the Union’s cofinancing rate for these Member States, which have difficulty using EU funds at a time when they are most needed, due to the amounts of cofinancing required. In other words, this represents an increase in the Community contribution to 95% of EU cofinancing, particularly for regions eligible under the convergence objective and the outermost regions, while for the other regions, there will be an increase to 85% until the end of 2013.

However, this proposal by the Commission does not include – as it should – the budget at the disposal of each of the countries that are in difficulty, so the practical result, owing to the reduction in national contributions, will be a reduction in the overall sum intended for investing. There is therefore a need for the Commission to consider actually increasing the Union funding available to these countries, as well as abolishing the irrational criteria of the SGP, thus freeing up the necessary public investment.

Against this backdrop, the Commission proposes temporarily increasing the Union’s maximum cofinancing rate for programmes running in Member States which receive support under the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism (currently Greece, Ireland and Portugal) and the balance of payments facility for non-euro area Member States (currently Latvia and Romania). In view of the current budgetary constraints, Portugal will thus have the possibility of fulfilling its commitments to cofinanced Community programmes, namely, the structural and cohesion funds, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Fisheries Fund. It should, however, be noted that this hope that EU funding will be made available does not preclude the high risk that there will be a failure in take-up or reduction in applications for new projects before the end of the financial period in 2013, causing a slowdown in investment in rural economies.

 
  
 		 

  Aldo Patriciello (PPE), in writing. – (IT) Considering that as a consequence of the financial and budgetary crisis, some Member States are facing budgetary constraints which might prevent them from fulfilling their commitments in cofinanced Community programmes, I think it is opportune on this occasion to support the Commission’s proposal to temporarily increase the Union’s maximum cofinancing rate for programmes running in Member States that are subject to support from the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism. I therefore agree with all the amendments to the regulation and I vote in favour of the proposal so as to speed up the legislative procedure, so it can come into effect by the end of 2011.

 
  
 		 

  Marit Paulsen, Olle Schmidt and Cecilia Wikström (ALDE), in writing. – (SV) We have chosen to support this targeted, temporary measure to support those countries hardest hit by the deep financial crisis that the EU is experiencing. However, we would like to emphasise that these countries’ problems do not only consist of a lack of money. A better long-term solution would instead be to strengthen their ability to absorb the European programme funds that are made available within existing frameworks. This temporary amendment to the EU’s level of cofinancing must not therefore serve as a precedent for the future.

 
  
 		 

  Paulo Rangel (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The present crisis with which the Union is grappling has enabled the improvement of EU mechanisms for preventing systemic risk and for reacting to situations of economic and financial weakness. This has, firstly, allowed EU policy makers to focus their attention on the need to adopt structural instruments that will allow a faster response in the future to the different problems that may arise, and, secondly, has led to the adoption of measures that could alleviate the effects of the economic and financial crisis in the short term. The proposal to increase the EU cofinancing rate falls within the same area, in the context of the structural and cohesion funds, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Fisheries Fund, benefiting countries that are covered by the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism, or the balance of payments facility for those that do not belong to the euro area. This proposal deserves my vote in favour, and I hope that it will enable the speeding up of the process of Portugal’s economic recovery.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – In favour. As a consequence of the financial and budgetary crisis, some Member States are facing budgetary constraints which might prevent them from fulfilling their commitments in cofinanced Community programmes (structural and cohesion funds, EAFRD and European Fisheries Fund). These Member States are at the risk of losing the Community support through EAFRD unless they provide proof of spending matching national funds, as defined in Article 70 of Regulation (EC) No 1698/2005, at the latest 2 years after the year initially foreseen for the payment (n+2 rule). Against this background, the Commission proposes to temporarily increase the Union’s maximum cofinancing rate for programmes running in Member States that are subject to support by the EFSM (Council Regulation (EU) No 407/2010, currently Greece, Ireland and Portugal) and the balance of payment facility for non-eurozone Member States (Council Regulation (EC) No 332/2002, currently Latvia and Romania). This temporary increase in Community cofinancing, provided on application from the Member State concerned, would reduce the amount of matching national funds needed in budget years 2011 and 2012. It would thus help to make programmed funds available for the rural economy and contribute to an overall economic recovery in these Member States.

 
  
 		 

  Sergio Paolo Francesco Silvestris (PPE), in writing. – (IT) On account of the international financial crisis and the budgetary crises afflicting certain Member States, action is needed to support states in fulfilling their commitments, all of this in the spirit of solidarity which drives the European Union.

The provisions relating to financial management that we have voted on foresee no additional commitment appropriations, but ‘frontload’ the appropriations from 2013 to the two-year period 2011-2012. The current urgency makes this measure necessary.

With this vote, Member States will be able to temporarily increase the Union’s maximum cofinancing rate for Community programmes, such as the structural and cohesion funds, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) and the European Fisheries Fund.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Teixeira (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Due to the global economic and financial crisis, some EU Member States are facing serious budgetary constraints, which could make it impossible for them to fulfil their commitments in relation to the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development. This is the case with Portugal, Greece, Ireland, Romania and Latvia. With the aim of contributing to the efficient economic recovery of these Member States, the Commission has taken the initiative of increasing the rate of cofinancing by 10%, so that it covers 95% of the total costs of projects that come under the structural funds. I agree with this initiative as I believe that it will not lead to changes to the funding of cohesion policy, but rather to advancement in the funds granted to the Member States. In view of this, the countries in question will not be obliged to make a large contribution to Community projects, thus making it easier to boost initiatives that have already been approved in the application, as well as the leveraging of new actions.

 
  
 		 

  Silvia-Adriana Ţicău (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted for the proposal amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1698/2005 as regards certain provisions relating to financial management for certain Member States experiencing or threatened with serious difficulties with respect to their financial stability. Therefore, in order to facilitate the management of the funding granted by the EU, to support increasing the pace of investment in Member States and in the regions hit hard by the crisis, as well as to enhance the impact of the funding on the economy, the rate of the EAFRD contribution is permitted to be increased to up to 95% of eligible public expenditure in the areas eligible under the convergence objective, or to up to 85% of eligible public expenditure in other regions facing severe difficulties in terms of their financial stability.

This temporary increase in cofinancing rates must be examined in the context of the budgetary constraints which all Member States are facing. In fact, the relevant budgetary constraints should be reflected appropriately in the general EU budget. Furthermore, since the main aim of this mechanism is to resolve current specific problems, it should be applied for a limited period of time to the expenditure incurred by the paying agencies up to 31 December 2013.

 
  
 		 

  Angelika Werthmann (NI), in writing. – (DE) As a result of the financial and budgetary crisis, many Member States are unable to meet their commitments with regard to cofinanced European Union programmes. If these states cannot prove within two years of the year in which the payment is planned that they have made the funding available in accordance with Council Regulation (EC) No 1698/2005, they risk having the subsidy suspended by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD). A temporary increase in the highest rate of EU cofinancing will ensure that these countries can continue with their cofinanced projects. It will also prevent European Union support provided by the EAFRD from becoming unavailable. I have voted in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Iva Zanicchi (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted in favour of Mr De Castro’s report. As a consequence of the financial and budgetary crisis, some Member States are facing budgetary restraints which might prevent them from fulfilling their commitments in cofinanced Community programmes (structural and cohesion funds, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) and the European Fisheries Fund).

To remedy this situation, the Commission has proposed to temporarily increase the Union’s maximum cofinancing rate for programmes running in Member States that are subject to support from the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism (EFSM) (currently Greece, Ireland and Portugal) and the balance of payments facility for non-euro area Member States (currently Latvia and Romania).

This temporary increase in community cofinancing, provided on application of the Member State concerned, would reduce the amount of matching national funds needed in the budget years 2011 and 2012. It would thus help to make programmed funds available for the rural economy and contribute to an overall economic recovery in these Member States.

 
  
  

Report: Robert Sturdy (A7-0365/2011)

 
  
 		 

  Luís Paulo Alves (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I am voting for this report, as it clearly analyses the barriers and tariff policies that currently exist in trade involving EU Member States. In addition, I believe that it is important to seek to remove the existing barriers to European entrepreneurs who have difficulties in exporting to EU trading partners which impose serious barriers to European imports. It is necessary to respect the fact that the creation of tariffs also depends partly on national and regional choices, such as at the level of genetically modified organisms, but in general, we can send a message that closer cooperation between the world’s major trading partners will allow the economies of all the stakeholders to be revived. Finally, it is important to pay particular attention to the needs of developing countries.

 
  
 		 

  Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this resolution on trade and investment barriers. Open and fair trade is the best way to ensure and maintain a level playing field for European businesses competing at global level. The Commission must act proactively to remove or at the very least reduce the restrictive impact of non-tariff barriers (NTBs) on the capacity of European businesses to access foreign markets. I agree with the rapporteur that this must be a top priority of the new EU trade policy under the Europe 2020 strategy. The Commission should raise the issue of NTBs with all of the EU’s trading partners, above all, with the strategic partners with whom the EU does most of its trade. The EU should also carefully review its own trade measures in order to remove any illegitimate hindrances to open and free trade, and become a true frontrunner in the fight against NTBs.

 
  
 		 

  Elena Oana Antonescu (PPE), in writing. – (RO) Removing trade barriers is one of the most important actions which the EU authorities can take to be able to stimulate the competitiveness of the European Union’s economic operators. Providing European economic operators with free access to market outlets is intended to stimulate their competitiveness and innovative capability, as this is one of the European Union’s economic policy priorities.

The European Union has the duty, along with its trade partners and the European External Action Service, to define and renegotiate the technical and quality standards to prevent them from becoming non-tariff barriers blocking EU producers’ access to external markets. Negotiating transitional periods and consensual trade methods with the EU’s partners will help give a boost to European producers, in addition to protecting European production standards or geographical indications. The EU must also insist on ensuring the principle of reciprocity. Just as companies outside the EU can participate in public procurement procedures in the EU, European companies must also have free access to calls for tender from the authorities in foreign countries.

I voted in favour of this report.

 
  
 		 

  Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this report. EU companies with activities in third countries continue to face major barriers. Non-tariff barriers (NTBs) remain one of the greatest problems and refer to all trade restricting measures other than import duties (tariffs) that limit imports. NTBs include direct price influencers (such as export subsidies or drawbacks, countervailing and anti-dumping duties, exchange rate manipulations, methods of import valuation, customs surcharges, unreasonable standards and inspection procedures), and indirect price influencers (such as import licensing, import quotas and ‘voluntary’ export restraints). Removing or reducing unjustified NTBs and other regulatory obstacles applied by the EU’s key strategic partner countries by means of regulatory dialogue should be one of the key regulatory priorities of the new EU trade policy under the Europe 2020 strategy. The issue of access to public procurement for EU companies in third countries also needs to be addressed. Public procurement procedures in the EU’s strategic partner countries tend to be closed to foreign participants and are still relatively unaffected by international commitments, while the EU is much more open than other countries in this regard. Under EU law, European and foreign companies can tender for European public contracts without discrimination, and the EU must therefore become more involved and reach agreements with its main trading partners to give European companies fair and equitable access to procurement procedures in third countries.

 
  
 		 

  Sergio Berlato (PPE), in writing. – (IT) By Non-tariff barriers, which were first discussed as part of WTO multilateral trade negotiations in 1979, we mean all trade restricting measures which limit imports. I believe that open and, above all, fair trade is the best way to ensure and maintain a level playing field for EU businesses competing at the global level. The bilateral and plurilateral negotiations are also a good opportunity for the Commission to step up regulatory cooperation with the EU’s main trading partners. In my opinion, the Commission should act proactively to reduce the restrictive impact of non-tariff barriers on the capacity of European businesses to access foreign markets. This shall be a priority of the new EU trade policy under the Europe 2020 strategy. Furthermore, with respect to free trade agreements (FTAs) between the EU and third countries, it is vital to make sure that these provide sufficient reciprocity in market access and mutual benefits to both parties. The ultimate aim should be to limit disputes and the associated costs of those for European businesses, without prejudice to the quality of the resulting regulatory environment.

 
  
 		 

  Mara Bizzotto (EFD), in writing. – (IT) In my opinion, Europe is not doing enough to protect its industry and the service sector from its foreign competitors, which, in the meantime, are protecting themselves with internal protection measures which are much more robust and effective than our own.

In any case, during trade negotiations with the largest partners and in EU production legislation, we should try to take into account Europe’s need to balance trading conditions and the quality and quantity of non-tariff barriers between us and our trading partners.

I also think the issue of non-tariff barriers should be a part of all free trade agreements. We should look into the possibility of establishing an early warning mechanism to detect new unjustified barriers, and we should look again at the sensitive subject of the supply of raw materials. That is why I voted in favour of the Sturdy report.

 
  
 		 

  Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this report because it aims to draw attention to trade and investment barriers preventing European Union companies from accessing markets in third countries. This report draws particular attention to so-called non-tariff barriers (NTBs), which are direct or indirect price influencers. Such barriers include export subsidies or drawbacks, exchange rate manipulations, lengthy customs procedures, unreasonable standards and inspection procedures, as well as import licensing, import quotas or export restraints. In its report, the European Parliament therefore calls on the Commission, which is responsible for international negotiations on behalf of the EU, to fight more actively against NTBs in world trade fora. Parliament also calls on the Commission to pay more attention to ensuring that free trade agreements concluded between the EU and third countries adhere to the principle of reciprocity where market access is concerned. In other words, they should ensure mutual benefits for both contracting parties.

 
  
 		 

  Vito Bonsignore (PPE), in writing. – (IT) The report presented was high quality and I voted in favour of it, since it deals with a subject that is very sensitive, that of non-tariff barriers, in the climate of financial crisis that Europe is currently experiencing.

Companies, European exporters, analysts and the Commission have identified non-tariff barriers as a growing hindrance to free access to partner countries’ markets; other than duties, these are trade restricting measures that limit imports. There are two main types: direct price influencers such as export subsidies or drawbacks, and indirect price influencers such as import licensing.

These are measures therefore of a potentially legitimate nature, but are often misused. The Commission must act proactively to reduce the impact of these barriers on the capacity of European businesses to access foreign markets.

In this context, the European Union should address the issue with a holistic strategy, reviewing trade measures, in order to remove illegitimate barriers and pay particular attention to current and future free trade agreements, making sure that there is sufficient reciprocity in market access and also making provision for bilateral safeguard mechanisms which include appropriate corrective measures.

 
  
 		 

  Philippe Boulland (PPE), in writing. – (FR) If we are to help our companies gain market share abroad, we must not only demand the removal of barriers restricting trade between the European Union and its trading partners, but also secure reciprocity of market access. To this end, we must keep an up-to-date inventory of these barriers and put in place an early warning system. In view of the rapid growth in global trade outside the European Union, the Commission must urgently draw up a legislative proposal on an instrument for reciprocity in respect of access to third-country government procurement markets. The impact of foreign direct investment on the internal market also needs to be evaluated so as to forestall any potential adverse effects on European innovation and know-how in certain strategic sectors. Our European companies are internationally recognised for their know-how in the fields of infrastructure, transport, construction and advanced technology. Therefore, it is up to us to do all we can to enable them to access new markets.

 
  
 		 

  Lara Comi (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted in favour of this report because I think globalisation only has positive effects when we can control the direction it takes. My generation on this continent has access to a range of goods and services that would be unimaginable in other periods of history and in other parts of the world. At the same time, the opening of international trade has allowed the economy to grow from strength to strength, with positive effects for the majority of citizens. This does not mean that we should not consider balancing measures, which, despite themselves, make us more exposed on the international market, and on the subject of equality, we cannot allow barriers which protect inefficiencies that are of exclusive advantage to the few people who benefit from them. I wait to see the Commission’s proposal on this issue for further increasing the wellbeing of European citizens.

 
  
 		 

  George Sabin Cutaş (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted for this resolution because the World Trade Organisation is the most suitable forum for regulating free and fair trade globally. On the other hand, we need to reform the way the WTO operates and its decision-making process to eliminate the lack of democracy.

I find it regrettable that several developing countries largely open to trade had to suffer due to the economic crisis, especially in the form of job losses. I think that the European Union must play a strong role in the negotiations for concluding the Doha Development Agenda by promoting the interests of the least developed or developing countries. We must think of the needs of weak states and create fairer rules for them through the auspices of the WTO.

 
  
 		 

  Vasilica Viorica Dăncilă (S&D), in writing. – (RO) Trade relations with countries from all over the world have always provided and continue to provide a basis for developing economic relations with these states at every level. As these relations are very often hampered by various barriers, I think that the proposal for the European Commission to examine the possibility of introducing an early warning mechanism to detect such barriers is useful.

While in the midst of developing the European External Action Service’s activities, I believe that the EU must consider getting more involved in EU missions precisely so as to be able to identify such barriers in good time and find solutions for avoiding stalemate in trade relations with third countries and, in particular, any stalemate hampering investors.

 
  
 		 

  Mário David (PPE), in writing. – (PT) In addition to its comprehensive, properly contextualised analysis, this own-initiative report by my fellow Member of the Committee on International Trade, Mr Sturdy, proposes various concrete measures aimed at promoting free trade on a global scale, in line with the rules set out by the World Trade Organisation. In the 15 pages of his report, which I recommend that all those who are interested in matters relating to international trade read, especially in relation to its legislative framework in recent years, I would also emphasise the need to eliminate non-tariff barriers to trade and investment, as one of the main objectives of EU trade policy under the Europe 2020 strategy. Of the many corrective and preventative measures that it proposes, I would like to highlight only one: that the Commission should study an early warning system to detect non-tariff barriers, and the strengthening of its existing analytical tools for the better qualitative evaluation of these barriers. From what I have said thus far, it is easy to see that I have voted for the report, and I would like to congratulate Mr Sturdy for the excellent work that he has carried out.

 
  
 		 

  Anne Delvaux (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I believe that the removal or, at the very least, the reduction of non-tariff barriers and other regulatory barriers should be a priority in the regulations concerning the Union’s new trade policy under the Europe 2020 strategy. Hence, I believe it is vital to call on the Commission to systematically address non-tariff barriers as part of a holistic strategy, including enhanced regulatory dialogue, with respect to all the EU’s trading partners. Furthermore, it is important to improve regulatory cooperation and convergence of regulatory requirements on the basis of international standards and, where possible, engage in regulatory dialogue to address existing or potential future barriers to trade with a view to limiting disputes and their associated significant trade costs.

 
  
 		 

  Edite Estrela (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I voted for the report as I believe that it is going in the right direction by promoting the combating of unfair competition, the elimination of unjustified non-tariff barriers, the strengthening of respect for intellectual property rights, protection for EU consumers and, in particular, the protection of the environment inside and outside the EU.

 
  
 		 

  Diogo Feio (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The freedom of trade and rejection of protectionism are defining elements of the European project, such as it is. The EU is based on freedom of movement within its borders, but also on freedom of trade and investment with third countries. This is the correct model, and I am not asking for it to be reviewed.

However, as the French President rightly pointed out only last week in Marseille, we cannot impose quality standards on our producers and industries if these are not then met by the products that we import. In the same way, we cannot be a more open space, yet fail to see our openness to imports and foreign investment reciprocated with acceptance by other important markets that Europeans want to enter. Finally, free trade agreements, which are important and opportune, need to be reciprocal, as otherwise we will be condemning the European economy to a slow death.

 
  
 		 

  José Manuel Fernandes (PPE), in writing. – (PT) This report concerns the barriers to trade and investment in the European Union, which hinder competitiveness, economic growth and thus wealth creation and employment. As the rapporteur, Mr Sturdy, says, ‘open and fair trade is the best way to ensure and maintain a level playing field for European businesses competing at global level’. The issue of barriers to trade and investment has been subject to a multilevel approach: the Transatlantic Economic Council has decided to strengthen cooperation between the US and the EU, in accordance with the Trade Principles for Information and Communication Technology Services. Progress has also been noted in the automotive sector, and a high-level conference is expected to take place. All this shows that the elimination of barriers to trade is a priority for the EU. Although I agree with the opening up recommended in the report, and therefore voted for it, I also believe that a mechanism should be created under the World Trade Organisation to speed up the elimination of non-tariff barriers in a peaceful yet efficient way, or by regulatory measures on trade that limit imports.

 
  
 		 

  João Ferreira (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) The rapporteur gives the impression of being a staunch defender of free trade, and it is this vision that prevails in the report. This vision is in line with the dominant positions in Parliament, uniting the right with the social democrats. We consider the content of this report to be unacceptable.

We are looking at yet another defence of the unbridled liberalisation and deregulation of international trade. Despite the recognition that among the so-called barriers to trade, there are practices, regulations and procedures that are justified on the basic grounds of public interest, they are seeking to restrict these barriers as much as possible, upholding a restrictive view of the public interest. They want to force various countries to lift their non-tariff barriers in the name of the free movement of products from the EU, to combat favouritism towards national companies.

The liberalisation of world trade has disastrous consequences for many sectors of economic activity. It causes the destruction of productive activity and jobs, affects the capacity to create and distribute wealth, increases the dependence on foreign markets and results in chronic and growing imbalances in trade; in short, economic and social breakdown. Defending the right of each country to produce in a sustainable way is vital for the future. This should be done in the name of a new economic, social, energy-oriented and environmental rationale, something that the neoliberal model not only fails to deliver but even renders impossible.

  Monika Flašíková Benová (S&D), in writing. – (SK) The rule-based multilateral trading system, which was established under the aegis of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), is the most suitable framework for regulating and promoting open and fair trade and guaranteeing the development of fair and equitable global trade rules.   Brice Hortefeux (PPE), in writing. – (FR) Freedom of movement is one of the founding principles of the European Economic Community, and in a world in which the drawbacks of economic interdependence have also been revealed, it is essential to lay the foundations for fairer trade, with respect shown for the principle of reciprocity. By 2015, 90% of global growth will be generated outside the European Union. This is a parameter we cannot ignore. The future of our companies will also be at stake outside our borders.   Juozas Imbrasas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour because the EU should actively defend its industries, whenever necessary, against violations of agreed rules and WTO standards and principles by its trading partners using all available means, including multilateral and bilateral dispute settlement mechanisms and WTO-compatible trade defence instruments.   Mario Mauro (PPE), in writing. – (IT) Non-tariff barriers (NTBs) should be given at least as much attention as is currently afforded tariff elimination in all appropriate regulatory fora. This would be a significant step forwards as part of the trade negotiations that the EU is developing in the world. I voted for this report for these reasons.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Melo (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Given that the issue of non-tariff barriers, which are a growing hindrance to free access to partner countries’ markets, include a series of trade restricting measures other than import duties, which limit imports, it is important that the Commission acts in a proactive way to eliminate or at least reduce the restrictive impact of such non-tariff barriers, so that the export capacity of European countries is not affected, and thus ensure and maintain equitable competitive conditions for European companies that are competing in the global market.

 
  
 		 

  Rareş-Lucian Niculescu (PPE), in writing. – (RO) I voted for this report because, apart from lifting the trade barriers hindering trade between the EU and its trade partners, we must also establish reciprocity in terms of market access. This will enable us to increase European companies’ chances of winning larger shares of the foreign market. This is an important consideration, given that by 2015, 90% of global economic growth will be generated outside the European Union, and we must help European investors capitalise on all the existing opportunities.

 
  
 		 

  Rolandas Paksas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this resolution. I believe that, given the current economic situation, particular attention must be paid to trade and investment barriers faced by the European services sector. It should be noted that non-tariff measures and various crisis measures are particularly important given the higher added value of the services sector and the EU’s position as the largest exporter of services. It is very important for the EU to actively defend its industries and demand that the EU’s key strategic partner countries remove unjustified NTBs and other regulatory obstacles, or at least reduce their scope.

 
  
 		 

  Alfredo Pallone (PPE), in writing. – (IT) The liberalisation of trade and investments can bring only advantages and thus, I voted in favour of the report. The benefits of an open market are clearly greater and best felt in those countries which have eliminated customs duties and non-tariff barriers, restrictions that prevent European businesses trading freely with foreign markets, which would undoubtedly represent a considerable benefit, increasing demand for goods and common wealth. At a time like this, the global economy needs to support itself and cooperate in order to bring about recovery as soon as possible.

 
  
 		 

  Georgios Papanikolaou (PPE), in writing. – (EL) I voted in favour of the own-initiative report. Non-tariff barriers, which appear in various forms (anti-dumping duties, exchange rate manipulations, methods of import valuation, customs surcharges and so forth), are technical, complicated and sensitive from a political and social point of view, because certain measures are applied by governments in the general interest. However, some NTBs exert a restrictive effect on the ability of European undertakings to penetrate foreign markets. The EU’s new trade policy within the framework of the EU 2020 strategy should therefore be more outward-looking, so that, where feasible, the Commission can enter into agreement with the EU’s main trading partners in order to eliminate any restrictive and protectionist arrangements that cause commercial distortions.

 
  
 		 

  Maria do Céu Patrão Neves (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The most sensible way of finding the right balance between trading partners is the existence of an open market, albeit one which is offset with particular exceptions, which protects certain sensitive sectors of the economy for each partner, in order to enable it to adjust gradually and prepare itself for global competition before actually opening itself up to it. I voted for this report because I believe that this legislation supports this objective.

 
  
 		 

  Aldo Patriciello (PPE), in writing. – (IT) Considering that open and fair trade is the best way to ensure and maintain a level playing field for European businesses competing at the global level, non-tariff barriers (NTBs) represent a form of trade restriction on imports. Hence, the Commission should act proactively to remove or at the very least reduce the restrictive impact of NTBs on the capacity of European businesses to access foreign markets. I agree with all the amendments tabled on the report, and I voted in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Paulo Rangel (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The European Union, when seen from a dual perspective, is committed to a project for economic order based on the liberalisation of trade. Firstly, it deals with the purpose of the internal market, and secondly, it covers something about the regulation put forward by the World Trade Organisation, with which the EU is associated. Whatever the basic position that it adopts in this regard, it is certain that, within loose limits, a system of free intermediation in trade translates into what has been called a win-win situation; both the countries, or group of countries, which give up a more protectionist approach will end up making more profit together than individually. In view of this, the reduction of non-tariff barriers is justified, through subtle ways of introducing limitations on international trade, such as export subsidies, anti-dumping duties and exchange rate manipulations. These are barriers that do not follow the ‘formal’ method of introducing a tariff duty. In view of what has been said, a policy action aimed at the gradual abolition of these instruments is justified, while full commitment should be maintained to a system of exceptions, especially for weaker sectors of the economy. I therefore voted in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Crescenzio Rivellini (PPE), in writing. – (IT) During the part-session in Strasbourg today, we voted on the report by Mr Sturdy on reducing and removing trade barriers and unjustified regulatory obstacles applied by the EU’s strategic partners to trade and investment.

It was considered that the European Union, which has sole competence over trade and investment, should address non-tariff barriers (NTBs) as part of the Europe 2020 strategy, bringing together both a diplomatic effort to be pursued in close cooperation with the European External Action Service (EEAS), and an enhanced regulatory dialogue with the EU’s trade partners, in order to put NTBs at the heart of international negotiations.

It was also hoped that the World Trade Organisation (WTO) and the Commission would work together to underline the advantages of trade liberalisation so that the European Union can fully enjoy the opportunities of an open market, while at the same time offsetting possible negative externalities of widespread liberalisation by mutually agreeing with their trade partners on certain transitional exceptions.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – Abstention. The rapporteur has acknowledged that his main position was to fight protectionism in all its forms. He believes that open and fair trade is the best way to ensure and maintain a level playing field for European businesses competing at the global level. He maintains that he has always been a strong supporter of the multilateral trading system, and defends the rules established within the WTO framework as the best means to ensure equitable treatment for all global trading partners. We Greens agree on some important points of the proposal. However, we would have preferred to vote down some of the recitals (G, L, M, N and O). We tried and we failed. So, in the end, we have abstained.

 
  
 		 

  Oreste Rossi (EFD), in writing. – (IT) I am in favour of the report’s text which defines non-tariff barriers as all trade restricting measures other than import duties that limit imports. These measures may influence the price of goods directly, for example, export subsidies or drawbacks, or indirectly, for example, through import licensing and import quotas.

The issue of non-tariff trade barriers is recognised in the report’s text as being technically and politically sensitive because some of these measures are being implemented by governments in the public interest. I think we need to find the right balance between trade openness and temporary market closures using the institution of transitional exceptions through mutual agreements with trade partners.

 
  
 		 

  Tokia Saïfi (PPE), in writing. – (FR) For the first time this year, the European Commission has taken an inventory of the trade and investment barriers faced by our companies in third-country markets. This initiative, which I welcome, will better enable us to combat these barriers and therefore help to open up new markets. The European Parliament’s report, which concerns this inventory, proposes additional solutions, two of which seem particularly interesting to me. Firstly, keeping an up-to-date inventory of these barriers, which companies could consult to better prepare themselves before entering a market. Secondly, putting in place an early warning mechanism based on the expertise and local knowledge of the EU delegations and foreign embassies and consulates. These two solutions can be implemented quickly without generating new costs. That is why I supported them in the vote.

 
  
 		 

  Matteo Salvini (EFD), in writing, – (IT) I voted for this report. The rapporteur, Mr Sturdy, and the Committee on International Trade (INTA) have done excellent work. In any case, it is right to emphasise that certain states may raise barriers to legitimately protect their own economy and their own consumers. Of course, the text is lacking one important consideration which is that at some point, even the European Union might need to start protecting its own fabric of production rather than limiting itself to only requesting reductions in duties and the removal of non-tariff barriers. In my opinion, a real trade policy should not limit itself to this alone and should consider the interests of European small and medium-sized enterprises first and foremost.

 
  
 		 

  Sergio Paolo Francesco Silvestris (PPE), in writing. – (IT) European producers often find it difficult to penetrate and trade competitively in Eastern markets, particularly in the automotive, aviation and aeronautics sectors. It is therefore necessary to remove trade and investment barriers in order to create a fair and open market.

Bilateral and plurilateral negotiations are a good opportunity to step up regulatory cooperation with the principal EU partners as part of High-Level Dialogues. These instruments should be increasingly used to promote equivalence and convergence of international standards in all sectors, including public procurement. This vote underlines the importance of reducing the restrictive impact of non-tariff barriers on the capacity of European businesses to access foreign markets.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Teixeira (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The multilateral trade system represents the most suitable framework for regulating and promoting open and fair trade, as well as guaranteeing that fair and equitable global trade rules are developed across countries. However, European companies have serious difficulties in establishing themselves in some markets, particularly in China, Brazil and Argentina, where measures restricting trade in European products have been adopted. I am voting for this report as I believe that non-tariff barriers to European countries should be eliminated or reduced, and that international regulatory cooperation should be improved, foreign direct investment to the European economy encouraged in key markets, and a stable and attractive environment for European investors abroad promoted. Finally, I believe that the Commission should make every effort to draw up a complete and up-to-date inventory of the key barriers faced by EU companies.

 
  
 		 

  Silvia-Adriana Ţicău (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted for the European Parliament resolution on trade and investment barriers because I think that removing or reducing unjustified non-tariff barriers (NTBs) and other regulatory obstacles applied by the EU’s key strategic partner countries by means of regulatory dialogue should be one of the priorities of the EU’s new trade policy. We call on the Commission to address these issues in all multilateral and bilateral trade agreements, especially in Free Trade Agreements, and to ensure that NTBs are given at least as much attention as is currently afforded tariff elimination in all the appropriate regulatory forums, particularly during its negotiations with industrialised and emerging economies.

I think that due priority should be given to trade and investment barriers that affect European service sectors, including IT and telecommunications, financial services, construction, retail and distribution. We call on the Commission to pursue, with regard to raw materials, a sustainable, comprehensive and cross-sector strategy so that the export restrictions and taxes applied by some countries to raw materials do not affect global economic development and the fulfilment of the Europe 2020 strategy objectives.

 
  
 		 

  Derek Vaughan (S&D), in writing. – European businesses competing at a global level should not be hindered by non-tariff barriers (NTBs), which can hamper free access to partner countries’ markets. The Commission needs to act to reduce the negative impact of unjustified NTBs, which are a barrier to trade. The EU needs to examine its trade measures in order to make sure that trade is made as open and free as possible. Trade policy should be a priority for the EU 2020 strategy and I echo calls for the Commission to address problems with the existing WTO Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade. I support the view that an early warning system be set up to identify NTBs that pose risks to trade.

 
  
 		 

  Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (FR) I voted against this report, which lauds ultraliberal dogma: ‘Let us remove all barriers to global trade (we are talking about non-tariff barriers here) and trade will bring prosperity to all those who make it their religion’. It goes without saying that in the middle of an economic crisis, where each day brings a new batch of unemployed people and social outcasts, this text is a provocation that ignores worsening social inequalities and environmental issues. I refuse to accept this headlong flight into free trade, without rules and without morals. Trade is not simply a question of business and profits. It must allow for the movement of people, ideas and goods, taking each country and each population into account, and work towards building new relationships.

 
  
 		 

  Angelika Werthmann (NI), in writing. – (DE) Over the years, various trade barriers have caused major problems for the international market. One particularly sensitive area involves non-tariff trade barriers, which are often put in place by governments in what is allegedly the public interest. However, to a certain extent, they are at risk of being abused (protectionism under the guise of legitimate political objectives). Suitable measures for identifying and removing or reducing non-tariff barriers include free trade agreements between the EU and third countries, periodic reassessment of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) agreement, a joint engagement by the Commission and the European External Action Service (EEAS) with the EU’s trade partners and the establishment of an early warning mechanism. I have voted in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Iva Zanicchi (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted for the text presented by Mr Sturdy which analyses the restrictive measures facing international trade which have been adopted in recent years by the European Union’s major partners.

It can undoubtedly be said that the advantages of trade liberalisation are best felt in those countries that have eliminated tariffs and non-tariff barriers, fully enjoying the opportunities offered by the ‘open market’. Finding the right balance between trade openness and temporary market closures is essentially the equilibrium EU trade negotiators have to seek in the run-up to all trade negotiations, and especially free trade agreements.
